title: Hotel Digest: A Four Seasons in Seoul, Spa News and More (Published 2015)
author: Shivani Vora
description: What you need to know if you're on a trip or planning one soon, including the first Four Seasons hotel in Seoul, spa options at New York's Park Hyatt and ayurveda treatments at Peninsula Hotels.
cleaned_text: Supported by [SKIP ADVERTISEMENT](#after-sponsor) Hotel Digest: A Four Seasons in Seoul, Spa News and More Our weekday morning digest that includes information about hotels and resorts, with deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know. NEW SEOUL FOUR SEASONS Four Seasons continues its expansion through Asia. The luxury hotel brand is set to open its first hotel in Seoul on Oct. 15. The [Four Seasons Hotel Seoul](http://www.fourseasons.com/seoul/), in the city's Central Business District, will be the chain's first in South Korea and its 24th in Asia. The 317-room property will have seven restaurants, including an Italian and a Japanese restaurant, as well as a three-level gym and fitness club, The 65,000-square-foot space has a gym, exercise class studios like Pilates, three pools and a golf driving range. It will also have a Korean sauna with several bathing areas and a spa. Rooms from 445,000 won ($395) a night. PARK HYATT SPA [Spa Nalai](http://www.newyork.park.hyatt.com/en/hotel/activities/hotel-activities/spa.html) at the [ Park Hyatt New York](http://newyork.park.hyatt.com/en/hotel/home.html) recently introduced its International Series, a menu of services inspired by other Park Hyatt locations for a limited period of time. The current focus is Dubai: Spa guests can choose a 90-minute massage that uses oil made from ingredients found in Dubai, such as sage. Another option is the Gold Vitality facial, a 90-minute treatment featuring a 24-carat gold exfoliator. "When you think of Dubai, you think of gold and opulence, and through these treatments, we want to invoke a sense of place," says Lynne Bredfeldt, the Park Hyatt's New York director of public relations. Next up in the series is [Park Hyatt Zanzibar](http://zanzibar.park.hyatt.com/en/hotel/home.html). Prices from $350. AYURVEDA AT THE PENINSULA Ayurveda — the ancient Hindu practice of healing medicine — is now at [the Peninsula Hotels](http://www.peninsula.com/en/default). The Hong Kong-based chain, which has 10 locations worldwide, started a range of Vedic aromatherapy spa services called Sattva by Simply Peninsula and designed by the Australian spa brand, Subtle Energies. Eight new treatments combine classic ayurvedic methods with contemporary massage techniques such as lymphatic drainage while incorporating essential oils, Himalayan crystal salts, clays and herbs. Options include a Himalayan crystal salt body scrub and the Sattva Shirodhara, where warm oil is poured over the forehead to help soothe the nervous system. It is followed by a face massage with a second oil infused with Indian rose and tuberose. A line of Sattva by Simply Peninsula retail products will be available later this year. Prices from $205. PIZZA AT FEARRINGTON HOUSE INN Who can resist pizza followed by ice-cream? The [Fearrington House Inn](http://www.fearrington.com/the-fearrington-house-inn/), a Relais & Chateaux property in Pittsboro, N.C., is offering a new interpretation of this favorite duo. The inn recently installed a wood-fired oven in its beer garden, called the Roost. The executive chef Colin Bedford has created a rotating selection of pies in standard combinations, like mozzarella, tomato and basil, as well as more unexpected ones such as lobster, mascarpone cream, Gouda and watercress. Mr. Bedford has also come up with nine flavors of gelato, including key lime pie and brown butter pecan crunch. They're made in-house in small batches several times a week and use cream from a local farm. Pizzas start at $10, gelatos at $3.75. HOTEL OFFERS QUITO TOURS Come for the room, stay for a taste of history. [Casa Gangotena](http://www.casagangotena.com), a 31-room property situated in an 18th-century mansion in the heart of Quito, recently debuted a series of activities to provide guests with lessons about Ecuador's heritage. The free sessions last an hour and are organized each day. Options for hotel guests include tastings of chocolate made from cocoa plants grown in the country, walking tours of San Francisco Plaza, the city's major public square and historic center, and excursions to the El Alabado Museum to view its archaeological collections. Rooms from $420, with breakfast.
